result.execSummary:
The defendant Deanna Marie Johnson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manuf/Deliver Amphetamine(<=3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(e)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Deanna Marie Johnson

records.addlTxt:
11:07 AM   Defendant Deanna Marie Johnson in court with attorney Joseph James Kaupie.  Defendant Deanna Marie Johnson in custody.  Bruce Poquette appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty Kaupie presents the agreement of the parties that has been reached for four cases in which probation is revoked (15CF204,15CF154,17CF12,17CM188) and two new cases (18CF215 & 18CF317) that were assigned to Judge Yackel, but are now being heard by Judge Anderson for judicial economy as per the agreement of both Judges.
Atty Poquette adds that preliminary hearing would need to be addressed/waived in 18CF317 prior to proceeding, and that any previously ordered financial orders from the revoked cases would continue as ordered.  
11:23 am Atty Poquette makes statement.  Court inquires and State verifies any victims rights legislation if applicable has been complied with.  
11:28 am Atty Kaupie makes statement.   11:36 am Defendant makes statement.
11:41 Court: Will follow agreement.  

15CF154  Count #1   Probation has been revoked.   
Sentenced.  12 months county jail, zero credit, CONSECUTIVE to the sentence in 15CF204.  DE eligible for Huber, with consideration of family care and treatment needs.  Any previously ordered financial obligations remain as ordered, remaining balance to be converted to Clerk of Court collect, civil judgment entered, subject to tax intercept.
Sentencing hearing on revocation on April 17, 2019 at 11:00 am.
15CF154 & 15CF204 assigned to Judge John Anderson; 17CF12 & 17CM188 assigned to Judge John Yackel
JOSEPH KAUPIE REPLACING RYAN REID

Defendant Deanna M. Johnson in court with attorney Thomas A Starr.  Defendant Deanna M. Johnson in custody.  Bruce Robert Poquette appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  State recites agreement.
DE entered plea of NC to 15 CF 255 count 2, 15 CF 204 count 3 , 15 CF 154 and 17 CF 12 count 1.    DE advised of rights and penalties; DE waives rights; parties stipulate to facts.   Court asks Atty Starr if he was satisfied that his client knowingly and freely was entering into this agreement.  Atty Starr states yes.    Court further addressed the DE.
  Court finds defendant guilty count 2 in 15 CF 255, count 3 in 15 CF 204, 15 CF 154 and count 1 in 17 CF 12.

Court:  15 CF 255 count 2:  9 months county jail with credit for 27 days time served good time and huber to begin on/before 5/26/17 at 3:00 pm - DE will obtain day for day credit if successfully completes inpatient treatment - fine/costs $579.00 counts 1 and 3 are dismissed and read-in

15 CF 204 count 3:  Sentence w/held probation 4 years - fine/costs $1630.50 - 90 days consecutive to 15 CF 255  county jail credit for 2 days time served  - any counseling DOC may recommend - AODA and follow thru - pshychological assessment - take all medication as prescirbed and as prescribed- cognitive behavioral class - no possession of illegal drugs - not to enter an establsihment that sells alcohol for consumption on the premises- counts 1, 2 and 4 are dismissed and read-in - consecutive to 15 CF 255  / 16 CF 36 - 16 CM 136, 16 CT 216 are dismissed and read-in

15 CF 154:   Sentence w/held probation 4 years - fine/costs $1630.50 - Restitution to LCO of $80.00 - any counseling DOC may recommend - 16 days credit time served if probation is revoked -   concurrent to 15 CF 204  / 16 CF 36 - 16 CM 136, 16 CT 216 are dismissed and read-in
